statement.text: Radiation-induced carotid artery disease occurs years after neck irradiation for head and neck cancers, causing accelerated atherosclerosis with fibrotic, often long-segment stenosis that carries higher intervention risk.

explanation.intuition: Radiation to the neck (for cancer treatment) damages the blood vessel walls over years, causing them to scar and narrow faster than normal atherosclerosis. The tissue is stiff, friable, and harder to repair surgically.
explanation.key_insight: Radiation changes occur 10-20 years post-treatment. The disease is often longer segment, more fibrotic, and extends higher toward skull base. Wound healing is impaired, making CEA higher risk; CAS is often preferred.
explanation.technical_details: Pathology: radiation accelerates vasa vasorum damage, intimal fibrosis, medial necrosis. Latency: 10-20 years post-XRT. Distribution: often long-segment, extends more distal, bilateral. Challenges: fibrotic tissue difficult to endarterectomize, impaired wound healing, cranial nerve injury risk. Treatment preference: CAS often favored over CEA due to wound concerns, though restenosis rates may be higher. Surveillance: annual duplex in XRT patients.

clinical_features.pathology: Accelerated atherosclerosis with fibrosis and medial necrosis
clinical_features.treatment_preference: CAS often preferred due to wound healing concerns

clinical_pearls: Screen prior XRT patients annually with carotid duplex
